document.text: WORKER8 AT THE APPOMATTOX County Sanitary Landfill returned to their jobs the Tuesday after Memorial Day to find s large pile of rubble heaped np outside the gate to the dump. The refuse, which included tree limbs and a variety ef otter illegal materia Is, was placed directly to fro of a sign outlining what materials can not be placed in the green county damp boxes. Much ef the refuse in the heap was material which was, according to the sign, clearly Illegal. County Building Inspector BIU Caldwell said that If such actions continue, he will seek summonses for the persons breaking the law. Photo by Bill Sherrod

document.text: WHILE IT WAS short-lived, last Wednesdays snowfall created its problems for motorists while it lasted, this tractor-trailer pp j off Route 460 near Evergreen and went into the trees as a result of slippery road conditions. The driver of the truck was not hurt. Numerous other accidents occured aS a result of the snow, mostly fender benders. However, one resulted in the death of a 69-year-old county man Appomattox Countys first traffic fatility of 1981. Photo by Bill Sherrod. .

document.text: THIS SMALL FRAME HOU8E on Route 24 across from Dew Drop Inn Restaurant received extensive damage Tuesday in a fire which was reported to the Appomattox Volunteer Fire Department at 1217 p.m. The house was rented by Chester and Debbie Smith and their four children, none of whom were at home when the Maze started. No injuries were reported in the blaze, and Hs cause is under investigation. Photo by Bill Sherrod

From left to right, Mickey Russell, Mrs. The Lewis, Judy Volturo, Betty Ford, Karen McFadden, David Mullins and Danny McFadden watch as David OBrien puts check to the amount of 618 into the MDA fishbowl during the Labor Day Telethon. David has a very personal interest in the fight against Muscular Dystrophy. Several of hb cousins have lost their lives to the disease. For the past several years David has been active In the annual MDFA drives, winning a bicycle two years to succession for his high relieftfont Mrs. Judy Volturo MDA Campaign Chairman for Appomattox, announced late Monday that the total collected for this year is 2,825.72 ns compared to1,535 collected last year. document.text: Is came I away from the hometown gym - fith their fourth district win, a 45-35 decision over the Lady Bees. Yfl scoring Ruby Smith -had the hot hand again Friday night,  scoring an amazing 22 points j to lead Raiderette scorers in  the game. She was followed j by Karen Johnmn and Lolita RA1DERETTES ROBIN Martin and Raby Smith defend Preston, each with eight against BrookviUe Debbie Keys in varsity girls basket prints, Robin Martin with bug action Friday night at Appomattox. 11m local girls rive points, and Susan wou the gam e, 45-35 Photo by Bill Sherrod. Handy and Rhonda Jaggers, each with a point. . The Raiderettes jumped out to an early lead, 9-4, at the end of the first quarter. Appomattox led by a comfortable eight points, 22-16, as the first half ended. The third-quarter margin was seven points, 35-28, and the local girls had scored 45 points to the Lady Bees 36 when the final busier sounded. They were a lot burger than v we were, but we combined good defense, hustle and speed to beat them, said Coach Tolley. Accbrding to Tolley, four of the Brookville players were bigger than any of the Appomattox players. They played a slow-down game, the coach added, and our half-court press messed them up. - Tolley commended - the offensive performance of Ruby Smith, aAd cited the efforts of Karen Johnson, who came off the bench and did a tremendous job for us. The Raiderettes, with a 4-1 district record, are now in -fourth place behind .Liberty 6-0, Rustburg and Gretna, both have 5-1 records. -, , -I
